title: PERRIS: Veterans face newcomers for school board run
text:
By IMRAN GHORI / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 16, 2015 Updated: 7:14 p.m. PERRIS: Veterans face newcomers for school board run Print Photo Share Pin It 1 of 4 More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Virniecia Green-Jordan is running for re-election to the Perris school board in the Nov. 3 election. , GAIL WESSON, FILE PHOTO Related article » PERRIS SCHOOL BOARD Four candidates are running for two seats on the Perris school board. Trustee Area 2 and 4 are on the Nov. 3 ballot.
TRUSTEE AREA 2
Tom Elliott
Age: 69
Family: Married, three children, nine grandchildren.
Occupation: Retired teacher.
Education: Bachelor's and master's degrees in supervision teaching at Central Michigan University, administrative credentials at California Baptist University.
Community activities: Current board president, member of Perris School District board, 2007-present; vice president, Riverside County School Board Association.
Edward Garcia
Age: 35
Family: Single, two children.
Occupation: Security officer.
Education: Associate's degree in business administration, Everest College.
Community activities: former union steward and president, California School Employees Association, Chapter 567.
TRUSTEE AREA 4
Lynne Guthrie
Age: 50
Family: Married, three children.
Occupation: Homemaker.
Education: G.E.D.
Campaign phone/website: Lynne Guthrie for Perris School District trustee Facebook page.
Virniecia Green-Jordan
Age: 61
Family: Divorced, one son
Occupation: Special education teacher.
Education: Perris High School graduate. Bachelor's in psychology from UC Riverside, master's in special education for severely handicapped from Cal State San Bernardino, master's in counseling psychology from California Baptist University
Community activities: Member of Perris Elementary School District board; involved in starting up county one-stop social services/family resource centers in Perris, Jurupa Valley and Mecca; helped establish a Perris Valley youth, crime and prevention team; member of a strategic planning group to develop programs for underserved Perris Valley youth; executive director of Perris Valley Arts and Activities Committee.
Campaign phone/website: 951-238-9879, votegreenjordan.com
Two veteran incumbents will face off against two newcomers in the race for the Perris Elementary School District board.
The Nov. 3 election is the first in which voters will select trustees by district instead of at-large. In Area 2, incumbent Tom Elliott is being challenged by Edward Garcia. In Area 4, incumbent Virniecia Green-Jordan faces Lynne Guthrie.
The district serves kindergarten- through sixth-grade students in the Perris Valley area.
Elliott, 69, who spent 27 years as a teacher and continues to train new teachers through University of Phoenix, is running for his third term.
“The major strength I bring is experience in the field of education,” he said.
Elliott is board president and said the current board members have worked well as a team to improve the district with projects such as a new elementary school under construction, expansion of its dual immersion program for English-learner students and approval of a charter school specializing in performing arts and music.
Green-Jordan, 61, who has been on the board since 1985, except two years, wants to expand programs that prepare kids for science, technology, arts and health careers.
“To create 21st century leaders, it has to start at preschool,” said Green-Jordan, a special education teacher.
Garcia and Guthrie, who have not held political office before, are running as a team, calling each other running mates who will bring a fresh perspective.
Garcia, 35, a security officer for the Val Verde Unified School District, said the Perris school district needs to do a better job of improving employee morale. He said employees are not paid as well as neighboring districts and the leadership needs to improve communication.
“It just seems to have come to a standstill in terms of engaging the community,” he said.
Guthrie, 50, a homemaker, said one of her priorities is improving special education, noting that she has a granddaughter with Asperger syndrome. She also wants to see the district be better prepared in the event of a school shooting such as one that occured in Oregon recently.
“I’m doing this because I’m concerned about the safety and well-being of our youth,” Guthrie said.
